CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, August 31, 1957, pg. 1 reads: " 'I Had No Coca-Cola' - Mike Podalak (third from left), owner of Mike's Tavern, Clairton, charged with refusing to serve Negroes, testifies before Magistrate Harry B. Fitzgerald, and claims that he "had no Coca-Cola on Aug. 24," when George Dobson (far left) entered his place to purchase this soft drink. Podalak admitted that he directed Dobson to "go down the street to buy Coke."  After a stern lecture on State and Liquor Control Board laws, the alderman imposed costs of $21.70.  in picture, left to right, are Dobson, his wife, Mildred; Podalak, Mrs. Susie Podalak, wife of the tavern owner; Albert Sendlock, witness for the defendant, and Alderman Fitzgerald. - Teenie Harris Photo."
TitMainTitle: Plaintiffs George Dobson and wife Mildred Dobson, defendants Mike Podalak and wife Susie Podalak, and witness Albert Sendlock, facing Alderman Harry B. Fitzgerald in discrimination case
